Earnings are always a lottery to some kind of degree. We have seen instances of companies reporting good quarterly results, but the stock falling nevertheless, because people thought the results would be even better. High expectations cause high dissapointment when not met. On the other side, we have also seen bad quarterly results with the stock jumping, because 1. People found it was a good time to buy in big, raising demand, raising stock value. 2. The bad results were not as bad as people thought it would be. Low expectations cause low dissapointment when not met. Now for Intel, I personally think that a lot of damage to the stock value is already priced in. Since march 2024 the stock lost more than 50 on its value on basically the same news over and over. Bad results, layoffs, no competetive products yet. Right now people ARE expecting bad results. You need a lawyer to look at your employment contract and probably also some of the organizational documents for your company. This is a multifaceted question that deserves more attention than that of some random redditors.
Did you get stock or stock options?
1 for a founding engineer is common. You can look at YC companies as an example. Nobody gives a non cofounder 2

Two things did you get shares outright or a warrant option to buy shares? Is your company public or private? If your company is private there could be a difference in what share price is in terms of grant vs current market value. ESOPs or share grants for LLCs are typically based off a 409a analysis performed by an accounting firm rather than the then current market value. Theres sometimes a timing difference between the last 409a and the last capital raise or market check on share price depending on how small the company is. Smaller growth companys 409a analysis is more about the financial projections of the company since the last capital raise rather than the current perceived value of it. Its possible that the share price you see to calculate the value of your grant was done on the 409a but the actual value of the shares is higher. If you got options than its in your interest for share price to be low at the time of grant.
0.03 might be the par value and not the market value

This is all red flag territory. As others have pointed out, perhaps you should consider quitting. From what you described, a 9010 split on 65,000 per annum would be 58.5k in cash and 6.5k in shares. Depending on the share price e.g. 0.03 per share 216k shares you would get more or less shares. You mentioned options agreement... Are you getting shares or share options? If youre getting options, you are not actually being paid in shares but the option to buy an amount of shares at an agreed price at a point in time in the future. If youre getting shares, then its effectively a form of debtequity swap, i.e. the business is servicing its debt to you by paying you in equity. In that case the share price may change over time, depending on the circumstances of the business at that time.

Given the state of the company you describe theyre probably not worth anything. If you have no other documentation and the company wont help proving anything may be difficult. Also, were these shares or options? Because in your first post you call them shares and here options.

Ive worked at startups before and this is hard to answer without seeing the full term sheet. What I will say is Exercise price is what youre buying it for, not what its worth. What its worth is hard to say with a private company, as they usually dictate when and who you can sell to.

Exercise price means you got options not shares. You strike or buy shares at 0.03. Theyre worth whatever the current FMV of them are. This a good thing. If share price is 1, you net 0.97. If it was higher you net less.

No employee that was furloughed would ever get 10 percent of the option pool. Options are not shares, theyre the right to buy them, often with stipulations like, you gotta be working for the company to earn them. Most option pools are 10 to 20 percent for the entirety of a companies employees.

Worth noting that options expire, and often rapidly for people who are no longer staff, so if these options havent been executed, you may be at risk of owning nothing. You need to read all the paperwork or follow up with the CFO.

Options are equity. Options lock in the price. If the options havent expired, you can sell them or exercise themwhich will require you to pay the strike price x quantityand 1 option usually represents 100 shares. Most people sell options, rather than exercise themsince youd have to have the cash to buy the shares at the contractual price. Options are an equity contract. You have right to buy at x price by y date, and this contract is a sellable asset.

i think theres a fundamental misunderstanding. you have 0 equity in the company. you have the right to purchase equity, at your strike price of 3 cents. however, if you choose not to exercise it which means purchasing the shares at 3 cents a piece, 100 shares per contract, the option will expire worthless. this is called a stock option. this is different than a RSU, a restricted stock unit, that takes time to vest. this would be given to you up front, and does not require you to purchase. you should also know that startup shares are usually worthless. it can only be sold in a liquidation event, where a company will raise capital by selling shares, either creating them or allowing employees to sell them. Or in an IPO. other than that, its almost impossible to sell shares

replies.text: Look into the wheel option strategy. Use the cash obtained from your assigned soldcalls to then sell a cash secured put so you will actually be paid on the other side of the transaction to buy back into the stock if it falls in price again.
What if the stock shoots to 105? And your buy of 101.1 never executes? Chances are it wont work out like you want to.

You can also buy back the option and sell a new covered call at a higher strike price. The problem with selling and buying the stock back is youre missing out on long term capital gains. If the option on the last day is above your strike price you can buy it back at a loss but then sell another covered call at a higher strike price. You just have to have enough cash on hand because depending on how high the stock goes it can be expensive to buy back.

This is what I was describing, I think. I wouldnt really be missing out on the capital gains because I would be buying back the stock at approximately the same price I sold it at. So if I bought it for 10k, sold it at 11k and then immediately bought it back at 10.95k I would be losing .05 there but still making .95 on the initial investment. Plus by selling the covered calls I could make an additional whatever amount. The trick would be to buy it back quickly enough to not let the price run away from me before the buy could execute, if its on a steep bullish run. I suppose with smaller volumes this would be a more feasible tactic because I could fill the order more quickly.

I dont hold any of AMD and Google just because I am still incredibly confused as to what their goals are. Personally I dont think Google will outpace NVIDIA and they are two different companies. Google is software and Nvidia is hardware CUDA which isnt really a replicable software. Googles direct competitor is Microsoft and somehow META. I just think that Googles software side is incredibly replicable and that the shift from perspectives that their sales are gonna go from ads to AI will have a tough time. On the software end, I got Microsoft or even META. META just because Gen AI tools is going to be extremely connected to their biggest shtick which is content creator platforms, and the fact that META, IMHO, has the best AI research team. FAIR has been producing the best AI papers for the past years most esp in computer vision. People dont know that things such as Magic Eraser, Magic Lasso Tool root itself from METAs Segment Anything which is the most ground breaking thing in Computer Vision alongside Diffusion Models. Microsoft too have strong integrations with software from Teams to MS Office suite and Windows. Most underrated is Github and Github Copilot. They literally own a shit ton of free code to train LLM models. For AMD, I am not so well versed on their products. They wont be able to compete with NVIDIA some time in the future. Honestly, if I were them, I would just try to completely dunk on the sinking ship that is Intel and fabricate CPUs that tightly integrate with NVIDIA GPUs on cloud clusters i do have a local AMD Ryzen laptop with RTX i use for local small training of models. Current virtual machines right now still have Intel NVIDIA GPUs e.g. V100, A10G. If AMD will just focus on beating Intel instead of NVDA, they could just win the AI race alongside them. If NVIDIA gets tired of Intels bullshit, I can see them fabricating their own CPUs. NVIDIA will still be the strongest contender by a mile for atleast 57 years. I cant see anyone coming closely to rivaling their moat until then. Even if a war breaks out in Taiwan and new chips halt in production for some time, the remaining functioning data centers can still function IMO. One company that I suggest worth looking at is definitely Qualcomm. They are trying to enter the desktop space and making the edge device phones, etc. much beefier to have its own Neural Processing Unit that are capable to run multimodal models. As phones get better in that, they have less need to access cloud servers which in turn means less need for GPU servers NVIDIA. Although Qualcomms direct competitor at that space is Apple which is gonna do the same. I am not an FI, but as an AI engineer, I am bullish on NVIDIA. I would definitely think that it is quite overhyped by people right now because it has been an AI arms race and every one is trying to race which AI product will be the first to profit. The purchasing will slow down. However, believe it or not, we are just scratching the surface for what AI can do. Diffusion models are just only around for about 3 years, LLMs for 2.5 years, and we havent reached those breakthroughs to the traditional AI real money makers yet such as detection and reinforcement learning but I have a feeling that it will come out sooner. But the thing is that comparing it to crypto is crazy because AI has business use cases and profitable as long as it has the proper market. NVIDIA is just creating more data centers to keep up with the cloud service demands from AWS, Azure, etc. but even if the demand gets low, they can always sell the access to services for cheap and still get money from it. But who knows, thats the free market for you.

I very much agree to the software side. A lot of useful google services embedded as extension to Gemini are helpful such as maps, workspace, photos on drive etc. Honestly at this point I cant no longer distinguish, on a meaningful level, between the performance of chatgpt and Gemini AI. Thats just me as a normal user going about daily googling and searching.

Innovators dilemma ? Why would Google want to be the first to put out AI results when its more expensive to generate those results AND less amenable to showing advertisements. But yeah, they could have led with that in their Cloud division.

replies.text: you just buy 10 bonds at auction. You will get whatever the auction price is. And yes, its going to be over 100 if the anticipated yield is 4.083 when it has a 4.125 coupon rate. I dont know exactly, but just using your guess of 103 would mean that if you put in an auction to buy 10 bonds and they are 103, you are going to end up paying 1031010 10300. So just have that much in your account.

Long dated bond funds like EDV have already risen like 1518 since the beginning of Q3 2024. The rate cut doesnt just happen and then your bonds are magically worth more. There price of the bonds are actively adjusted due to future expectations, so their yield is already dropping relative to current priced rate cut expectations. Rate cuts will have to occur faster than expected to outperform whats being priced.
That bond right now on the secondary market is 100.843 which gives a yield of 4.06. So if you plan on it being 101, that would probably be a safe estimate.
The rate cut doesnt just happen and then your bonds are magically worth more. The Fed does not set bond rates. A lot of people think they do.
Thanks, uspartybasketball . Thats really helpful!

Exactly, the market sets bond rates. Its not just sensitivity to the short term rate opportunity cost, its also inflation expectations, cost benefit of investments in the real economy, diversification goals, hedging, etc.
The tail wind is amazing and I would not fight the fed.
The Fed is reducing its holdings of Treasuries and the government is issuing 1 trillion of new debt each year.
And gdp grows 3 percent per year to cover most of the new trillion. The bigger question for rates of either candidate has the trifecta. Then you will see rates rise.

TLN with AWSAMZN for a buildout of up to 960MW data campus with 120MW already built out 2. CEG and MSFT have announced a partnership that is contingent on CEG starting up a unit at three mile island and alot of other contingencies, which if all come together would start earning CEG money in 202829 This leaves me to believe 1. Dualreactors are key to any colocation deal for now , because in single reactor plants most of VST nukes the power is shut off for planned maintenance outages, which makes the colocated data center immediately a taker of the utilities power supply aka the grid and that strips away most of the benefit to a behind the meter deal between the plant operator and data center tenant 2. States matter Tln was able to do the AMZN deal because their asset located in PA Susquehanna plant is a dual reactor which never received any state level subsidies to keep the plant open, compare that to states like IL,OH,NY,NJ, and a few more where good amount of CEG dual reactors are located, as well as VST single reactors who were compensated in the form of hourly credits per MWH to make sure the plants didnt shut down, these state programs require the plant operator to offer a larger amount of output to the state for years, in that period of time the state would have to grant signoff on any deal , and lastly the state would need to be incentivized to give up the baseload power they currently have locked in under these subsidy programs Lastly , I am not sure why NRG gets mentioned in this Nuke colocation theme, it is my understanding that NRG sold its last nuclear plant to CEG under pressure from Elliot management and proceeded to take the money and buyback shares , they are clearly riding the wave, long term NRGs model of owning less generation assets while growing the overall amount of power sold to customers seems it can run into problems if power pricing continues in its trajectory. You need to keep it under the assets column to declare amortization for 5 years for tax reasons. Real value after 1 year might be even megative value, because you need money to deinstall that particular machine.. The big picture is that different manufacturers processes are so specialized that their plants arent interchangeable. TSMC couldnt just buy out an Intel plant and start making TSMC wafers the next morning they would have to overhaul the whole facility. For example, Intel just bought a bunch of HighNA machines from ASML, and TSMC doesnt use HighNA in their processes. That equipment would be worth nothing to them at auction. So Intel is marking down these machines on their books as say 200M a piece of PPE book value, but they and the other fab equipment are deeply illiquid, and Intel couldnt actually resell them for 200M. I would be surprised if they could auction off their plants for a quarter of their book value. As far as Intels node 2nm is a marketing term, so take that with a grain of salt, and the big thing is that its yield and performance arent yet known. For comparison, Samsung claims to currently have a leadingedge 2nm process, but yields are reportedly 10. If they fab 10 chips on a wafer, they have to throw 9 away, so they cant get any orders and are bleeding money. And 18As performance isnt publicly known either. TSMCs CEO claims its on par with lastgen TSMC, but of course, he has every reason to slant things. Intel has released a design kit to customers in the last six months, and have got very few design wins outside of some defense stuff the US govt basically bullied firms into ordering, so I am not optimistic about 18A working out. But 18A is really where Intels future lies at.... all its eggs are in that basket. 18A has to work well, and has to fill a plant with orders running 247 at high yield in order for Intel to turn around. Anything short of that is looking like curtains.

As required human participation in the economy declines, an obvious question of what those humans would do for a living in such economic structure comes forward. Market economy cannot work unless there is a large pool of people who are able to sell their labor, and a more or less matching pool of businesses that are in need of it. You mess with one side of this balance and you get either inflation or worse deflation, when nobody can afford the goods the business makes even at break even point. Without a serious economic restructuring, that is where our economy will end up with AI help. The issue is, if left to own devices of current economic system, the restructuring will result in an economic crisis not seen from the time of the Great Depression. And, our heart bleeding conservatives do not want the government to move a finger short of changing one number. Because of the ideological reasons, because of the perverted misunderstanding of what the free market is. So let it burn! Be forewarned.

The question isnt whether liquid cooling is _technically_ superior, obviously it is. The problem is its monstrously more expensive to install, and then maintain on the daytoday. Just look at a server rack, look at all the cables and components, now imagine the practical hands on reality of a technician needing to work on any of that when its immersed in oil. Or even worse, it stays in the racks, but now theres an entire plumbing system of thousands of pipes where a single leak anywhere shuts down hundreds of servers. Why would you bother with any of that when you could just make the building 20 bigger and air cooling is still fine?

Alarming_Jacket3876 in another comment Its basic math. Levered ETFs attempt to double or whatever factor the daily price change of the underlier. This does not translate into a long term outperformance for a volatile index. Start with a price of 100. If the underlier goes down 5 percent, the fund goes down 10 to 90. Then if the underlier goes up 5, the fund goes up 10 which gets it to 99 only. Repeat over a long time and you will find a definite downward bias. The key here is that SSO doubles the daily price change so therefore the path daily up and down movements on how SPY gets to its current value matters. If it is a generally upwards trend over many days? SSO will outperform 2x SPY gains over that manyday period. If it is a slowgrind upwards or if there are large down days, then SSO will have less than 2x SPY gains. If the market is stagnant and SPY, then SSO will grind lower.

SpaceMobile is seen as the competitor to Elons Starlink. But investors are clamoring over ASTS claiming it has no rivals and dominates the space. No, it is targeting the D2C market, which Starlink and TMobile only began targeting AFTER they realized AST was indeed going to succeed in launching their test satellite. The timing and nature of the announcement were telling. So rather, Starlink is attempting to compete with AST. In the future, it is possible AST eats at Starlinks core market and viceversa, but thats down the road. So how many satellites does ASTS have in space? ZERO, with plans to launch their first sometime in the month of September. They have BW3. Which is a test satellite, I admit. But it did earn revenue from a gov contract. It is also the sane size as the current production satellites, but with 10x less processing bandwidth. It will assist in providing commercial services, though. But to say they have no satelllites is misleading because it implies we dont even know if their current model will work. It will. Starlinkl has over 5,000 satellites already in space that are fully operational and being used by consumers. Yes, for stationary wifi. Not cellular service. If youre thesis were true, Comcast wouldve bankrupted Verizon and ATT. But we all know that wasnt what happened. Even if you account for the D2C Starlink V2 minis, there are only around 100 with maybe 20 beams each? AST sats have 5600 each. They may only be launching 5 sats, but sat count ignores sat capabilities. ASTS will have a dilution fairly soon to raise further capital and will leave retail investors holding heavy bags. The stock skyrocketed specifically because they stated no more dilution in 2024 and probably none in 2025 as they target prepayments and ExIm financing. Currently it costs about 20m per sat, launch included. Prepayments from Voda, Verizon, and Att now average 4m, 20m, and 5m per sat respectively give or take conditional on successful launch, operation, and FCC approval, all of which are imminent. And that is only 3 of about 40 MNO partners contributing. Currently, if they did 5050 debtprepayment, each MNO would only have to prepay 400k per sat if they take 2 years to build with Opex at 120m per year. And why would MNO want to pay for the sats? Because thats a small price to pay for global coverage, no dead zones, reduced tower costs, improved service, emergency service for disasters, especially when you get half the ARPU. The list goes on. Sorry, but your estimation is ignorant of the reality of the situation. The price will vary a lot over the next two years, but at the end of the day, they now have a service that works, a product to launch, and 40 of the largest telecoms on Earth who want them to succeed, nevermind the US military. Edit just a note on my math 85 sats20msat120m opex32.060B40 mno85 sats2300ksat. I forgot how my napkin math earlier worked out to 400k, I had a reason, but didnt write it down.

The whole point of ASTS is that it has a patented technology for the signal to reach mobile phones without any additional equipment other than your phone as a receiver. Also, the business model of ASTS is smart, they will be offering their service through already established carriers, so they dont need to build up the distribution of their product. People will just have an additional option on their already existing mobile phone bill if they want to pay extra for global coverage and that will go to ASTS. Also, you cannot value a prerevenue company on a balance sheet data, are you dumb? That being said. Dilution is very likely if not certain. The durability of satelites is questionable, given just their sheer size largest sats ever put up to enable the transmission and especially signal receiving from earth, if there is any issue with space debree and one of the initial 5 is down, it could mean disaster. Global coverage is VERY VERY far away. And lastly are we sure EVERYONE is going to want to pay more for this fabled global coverage? Like, a grandma in maine is going to pay extra for this service? How many places are actually not covered by the existing 4g network already? Not that many actually. So ASTS is being priced as if the global adoption is a given, when in reality it could be that only adventurers and outdoors people will use the service. So yeah, id value this as a 1.21.6 billion market cap company atm. Definitely not 10b where its going currently.
